{{EngvarB|date=August 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Redirect|Prejudicial question|the legal term used in criminal, civil and common law|Prejudice (legal term)}} A '''preliminary ruling''' is a decision of the [[European Court of Justice]] (ECJ) on the interpretation of [[European Union law]], given in response to a request from a court or tribunal of a [[Member state of the European Union|European Union Member State]]. A preliminary ruling is a final determinations of EU law, with no scope for appeal. The ECJ hands down its decision to the referring court, which is then obliged to implement the ruling.
If, as in ''[[Factortame]]'', the ECJ holds that a Member State's legislation conflicts with EU law, the Member State will be required to "disapply" such law, but the ECJ may not itself amend the Member State's legislation.
Preliminary rulings have traditionally been issued by the ECJ. The [[Treaty of Lisbon]] provides that jurisdiction may be delegated the [[General Court (European Union)|General Court]], but this provision has yet to be put into effect.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Craig |first1=Paul |last2=de Búrca |first2=Gráinne |title=EU law: text, cases, and materials |date=2011 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=Oxford |isbn=9780199576999 |pages=482 |edition=5th}}</ref>
Preliminary Rulings make up the bulk of [[CJEU]] business, as few persons have ''[[locus standi]]'' to litigate in the Luxembourg court. "Privileged parties" that do have standing include all Member States and EU Institutions, but normally a private person or ''"undertaking"''<ref>An "undertaking" is EU-speak for a company, partnership or business firm. See TFEU Arts 101 & 102.</ref> will have standing only if they are the addressee of an [[Decision (European Union)|EU Decision]].
==Procedure== If a court or tribunal of a Member State finds a provision of EU law to be ambiguous, equivocal or unclear, it MAY seek a preliminary ruling; and if that court or tribunal is one from which there is no appeal, the court MUST make an application. In either case, the domestic court be be adjourned until the ECJ ruling is issued. The question to the ECJ must be short and succinct, but may be accompanied by documents explaining the context and circumstances of the issue. The ECJ may decline to give judgement in the absence of a genuine dispute, on the basis that it will not consider "moot points".<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61980J0244:EN:NOT Case 244/80, Pasquale Foglia v. Mariella Novello paragraph 18.]</ref>
Article 267 of the [[Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]] provides:
{{quote| The Court of Justice of the European Union shall have jurisdiction to give preliminary rulings concerning: {{plainlist| *(a) the interpretation of the [[Treaties of the European Union|Treaties]]; *(b) the validity and interpretation of acts of the institutions, bodies, offices or agencies of the Union;}} Where such a question is raised before any court or tribunal of a Member State, that court or tribunal may, if it considers that a decision on the question is necessary to enable it to give judgment, request the Court to give a ruling thereon.
Where any such question is raised in a case pending before a court or tribunal of a Member State against whose decisions there is no judicial remedy under national law, that court or tribunal shall bring the matter before the Court.
If such a question is raised in a case pending before a court or tribunal of a Member State with regard to a person in custody, the Court of Justice of the European Union shall act with the minimum of delay.<ref>Otherwise, an application to the ECJ may take a year or so before the question is answered.</ref>}}
==Courts that may ask questions== What constitutes a "court or tribunal" is a matter of Union law and it is not to be determined by reference to national law.<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61992J0024:EN:NOT Case C-24/92, ''Corbiau v Administration des Contributions'' at paragraph 15.]</ref> In determining whether or not a body is a "court or tribunal of Member State" the European Courts will take a number of issues into account, namely whether—
# it is established by law, # it is permanent, # its jurisdiction is compulsory, # it has an inter partes procedure, # it applies rules of law, and # it is independent.<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61996J0054:EN:NOT Case C-54/96 ''Dorsch Consult Ingenieurgesellschaft v Bundesbaugesellschaft Berlin'' at paragraph 23.]</ref>
However, these criteria are not absolute. In ''Broekmeulen v Huisarts Registratie Commissie''<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:61980J0246:EN:NOT Case 246/80, ''C. Broekmeulen v Huisarts Registratie Commissie'']</ref> the ECJ ruled that a body established under the auspices of the Royal Medical Society for the Promotion of Medicine was a "court or tribunal" within the meaning of the treaty, even though that society was a private association. Also the [[Benelux Court of Justice]] was considered a court within this context, as a court common to several (Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg) Member States. Also the [[Unified Patent Court]], as a court common to several Member States is expected to be able to ask prejudicial questions.
==Right and duty to refer for a preliminary ruling== Article 267 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) establishing the preliminary reference procedure differentiates between the right and the duty of national courts to seek a preliminary ruling. Under the discretionary reference stipulated in Article 267(2) TFEU, a national "court or tribunal" may ask the CJEU to give a preliminary ruling if it considers that a decision on the question is "necessary" to enable it to give a judgment in a particular case. The obligatory reference (duty to refer) is established in two cases: with respect to national courts adjudicating at last instance (Article 267(3) TFEU ) and with respect of all courts faced with a question of the validity of EU law. The obligation of national courts of last instance to refer for a preliminary ruling when a question of the interpretation of EU law arises is subject to certain exceptions. In accordance with the jurisprudence of the Court, a national court is relieved from the duty to refer (i) when EU law questions are not relevant to the decision in the main proceedings, (ii) in a situation before a national court is “materially identical with a question which has already been subject of a preliminary ruling in a similar case” (‘acte éclairé’), or (iii) when the proper interpretation of EU law is “so obvious as to leave no scope for any reasonable doubt” (‘acte clair’).<ref>Limante, Agne. Recent Developments in the Acte Clair Case Law of the EU Court of Justice: Towards a more Flexible Approach. JCMS: Journal of Common Market Studies, 2016, DOI: 10.1111/jcms.12434</ref>
== General scope of preliminary rulings == The Court of Justice Decision has the force of '''''res judicata'''''. It is binding not only on the national court on whose initiative the reference for a preliminary ruling was made but also on all of the national courts of the Member States.
In the context of a reference for a preliminary ruling concerning validity, if the European instrument is declared invalid all of the instruments adopted based on it are also invalid. It then falls to the competent European institutions to adopt a new instrument to rectify the situation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=URISERV%3Al14552|title=EUR-Lex|last=|first=|date=|website=eur-lex.europa.eu|publisher=|access-date=2016-12-01}}</ref>
==Ruling on non-EU cases== The European Court of Justice is competent to give rulings regarding the interpretation of treaties to which the European Union is a party, as those treaties are considered to be part of EU law. ECJ is however also competent regarding the application of certain treaties between EU member states, although the procedure may be subject to different procedures. Two such treaties are the [[1968 Brussels Convention]] on jurisdiction in civil and commercial matters and the 1980 Rome convention on applicable law (now mostly replaced by the Brussels I and Rome I regulations respectively).
==Similar systems== The possibility to ask for a preliminary ruling is also embedded in other legal systems. *The courts of Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg may ask "questions regarding the interpretation of the law" to the [[Benelux Court of Justice]] regarding certain Benelux conventions and regulations. *Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway may request the [[EFTA Court of Justice]] for an "advisory opinion" regarding the interpretation of the European Economic Area Agreement, as well as EU regulations that apply to those states.

Established in 2000, the '''Public Ministry of Paraguay''' is an autonomous body that has the following duties and powers per the Constitution:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ministeriopublico.gov.py/que-es-el-ministerio-publico-i3|title=¿Qué es el Ministerio Público? :: Ministerio Público|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ministeriopublico.gov.py|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oas.org/juridico/mla/sp/pry/sp_pry-int-text-minpub.html|title=Ley 1562/00|website=www.oas.org|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref>
* Ensure respect for rights and constitutional guarantees; * Promote public criminal action to defend the public and social heritage, the environment and other diffuse interests and rights of indigenous peoples; * Perform criminal action in cases in which, to initiate or prosecute, there is no need for a party, without prejudice to the judge or court proceeding ex officio, when determined by law; * Gather information from public officials for the performance of its duties, and; * The other duties and attributions established by law.
The ministry is headed by the Attorney General of Paraguay.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ortWAAAAYAAJ&q|title=Constitutions of the Countries of the World: Paraguay|last=Blaustein|first=Albert P.|last2=Flanz|first2=Gisbert H.|date=1971|publisher=Oceana Publications|isbn=9780379004670|language=en}}</ref> Sandra Quiñónez became the Attorney General in 2018, and she holds the distinction of being the first female to occupy the position.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.eldeber.com.bo/mundo/Primera-mujer-fiscal-general-de-Paraguay-asume-tras-polemico-proceso-20180310-0030.html|title=Primera mujer fiscal general de Paraguay asume bajo polémica {{!}} MUNDO {{!}} EL DEBER|last=DEBER|first=EL|website=www.eldeber.com.bo|access-date=2018-03-16}}</ref>

{{Other uses|The Reporters (disambiguation){{!}}The Reporters}} {{italic title}} '''''The Reporters''''' is a book on the subject of [[law report]]ers, written by [[John William Wallace]].
==Nineteenth-century reviews== In 1847, [[J. G. Marvin]] said of the second edition, revised, of this book:
{{Blockquote|Mr. Wallace has embodied, in one hundred pages, more useful information respecting the Reporters, than can be found in any single publication whatever. Mr. Sumner contributed two articles in the 8th and 12th volumes of the American Jurist, upon Legal Bibliography, and Mr. Ram, in his work entitled ''The Science of Legal Judgement'', collects many judicial criticisms upon the Reports and elementary law book, but in point of fulness of illustration, and appropriateness of comment, Mr. Wallace's volume, as to the Reporters, surpasses all that had previously been done. He confines his illustrations chiefly to the Reports, from the earliest period of reporting in England, to the close of the reign of Geo. II. Prefixed to the more immediate subject matter of the work, are some remarks upon the value to be placed upon the incidental observations of the Bench upon the merits of the Reporters, the original language in which the Reports were taken, the sources from whence the MSS. of the published volumes were obtained, and a general survey of the laborers in the "old fields, out of which the new corn must come." The work is written in a peculiar, and happy style, and impresses the reader favourably with the author's abundant reading, and aptness for communicating this species of information. The volume lacks only one thing, an Index. 6 L. R. 425.<ref>Marvin, J.G. [[Marvin's Legal Bibliography|Legal Bibliography, or a thesaurus of American, English, Irish and Scotch law books:together with some continental treatises]]. T & J W Johnson. 1847. Page 715. [https://books.google.com/books?id=DSNEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA715#v=onepage&q&f=false Digitised copy] from [[Google Books]].</ref>}}
In 1882, the New Jersey Law Journal said of the fourth edition, revised and enlarged, of this book:
{{Blockquote|A new edition of ''The Reporters'' is of real importance as a means of keeping alive a knowledge of the old reports. In the multiplication of law reports, made almost by machinery, there is a danger that the younger Bar will overlook the old ''Reporters'' and miss the treasures which they contain, and so have no acquaintance with the sources of the law.
''The Reporters'' is a delightful book - the last edition is even more entertaining than the others - and if it is only to be easily obtained it cannot fail of being generally read.<ref>The [[New Jersey Law Journal]]. Volume 5. Honeyman & Rowe. 1882. Page 128.</ref>}}
==Twentieth-century reviews== In 1988, Bookman's Yearbook said that this book was "well worth using".<ref>Bookman's Yearbook. Bookman's Weekly. 1988. Page 10.</ref>
Glanville Williams described this book as a "detailed monograph".<ref>[[Glanville Williams]]. [[Learning the Law]]. Eleventh Edition. Stevens. 1982. Page 37.</ref>
The Harvard Law Review said, in relation to [[Year Books|Year-Book]] bibliography, that this book discloses little that is valuable and its accuracy does not stand the test of verification.<ref>[[Harvard Law Review]]. 1900. Volume 14. Page 558.</ref>
==References== *Wallace, John WM. The Reporters chronologically arranged; with occasional Remarks upon their respective Merits. 2d edition, revised. 8vo. Philadelphia. 1845. *Wallace, John William. The Reporters. Third Edition Revised. T & J W Johnson. Philadelphia. 1855. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ne0yAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false Digitised copy] from Google Books. *Wallace, John William. The Reporters, arranged and characterized by John William Wallace. Fourth Edition. Revised and Enlarged. 1882. Digitised copies [https://archive.org/details/cu31924024518130] [https://archive.org/details/reportersarrang01willgoog] [https://archive.org/details/reportersarrang00willgoog] from Internet Archive. {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Reporters, The}} [[Category:Law books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:19th-century books]]

{{Infobox MP |name = Thio Li-ann | native_name = {{nobold|{{lang|zh-hans|张黎衍}}}} |honorific-suffix = |image = File:Thio Li-ann at a Human Rights Day seminar, Conrad Centennial Singapore - 20141204-01.jpg |caption = Thio speaking at a [[Human Rights Day]] seminar organized by the [[European Union]] Delegation to Singapore in December 2014 |office = [[Nominated Member of Parliament]] |parliament = 11th |term_start = 18 January 2007 |term_end = 17 July 2009 |appointer = [[S R Nathan]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1968|3|10|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Singapore]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[Singapore]]an |party = |spouse = |relations = {{plainlist| * Thio Su Mien {{small|(mother)}} * Josie Lau Meng Lee {{small|(cousin-in-law)}}}} |children = |alma_mater = {{plainlist| * [[Keble College, Oxford]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}} * [[Harvard Law School]] {{small|([[Master of Laws|LLM]])}} * [[University of Cambridge]] {{small|([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]])}}}} |occupation = [[legal education|Professor of law]] |website = |signature = |footnotes = }} {{Chinese name|[[Zhang (surname)|Thio]]}} '''Thio Li-ann''' ({{zh|s=张黎衍|zh|t=張黎衍|p=Zhāng Lí Yǎn}}; born 10 March 1968) is a [[Singapore]]an law professor at the [[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|National University of Singapore]]. She was educated at the [[University of Oxford]], [[Harvard Law School]] and the [[University of Cambridge]]. In January 2007, she was appointed a [[Nominated Member of Parliament]] (NMP) in [[Singapore]]'s 11th [[Parliament of Singapore|Parliament]].<ref>{{citation|author=Derrick Paulo|title=Citizen Thio goes to Parliament|url=http://www.todayonline.com/articles/166539.asp|newspaper=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]]|date=18 January 2007|format=}} {{dead link|date=June 2010}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Thio Li-ann was born in [[Singapore]] on 10 March 1968.<ref name="Parliament">{{citation|title=Prof THIO LI-ANN: Curriculum vitae |url=http://www.parliament.gov.sg/AboutUs/Org-MP-CV-NMP-ThioLA.htm |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iZkIZGgs?url=http://www.parliament.gov.sg/AboutUs/Org-MP-CV-NMP-ThioLA.htm |archivedate=27 July 2009 |publisher=[[Parliament of Singapore]] |date=25 January 2007 |accessdate=8 November 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}.</ref> Her mother is Dr. Thio (née Huang) Su Mien, former Dean of the [[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|Faculty of Law]] of the [[National University of Singapore]] (NUS) and presently Senior Executive Director of TSMP Law Corporation;<ref>{{citation|title=Dr Thio Su Mien|url=http://tsmplaw.com/directors-profiles/individual/dr-thio-su-mien-phd-london.html|publisher=TSMP Law Corporation|year=2007|accessdate=14 November 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229025715/http://tsmplaw.com/directors-profiles/individual/dr-thio-su-mien-phd-london.html|archivedate=29 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> her brother, Thio Shen Yi, is Joint Managing Director of the same law firm.<ref>{{citation|title=Thio Shen Yi|url=http://tsmplaw.com/directors-profiles/individual/thio-shen-yi-ma-cantab.html|publisher=TSMP Law Corporation|year=2007|accessdate=14 November 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229025220/http://tsmplaw.com/directors-profiles/individual/thio-shen-yi-ma-cantab.html|archivedate=29 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}.</ref>
Thio was educated at the [[Singapore Chinese Girls' School]] (1975–1984) and [[Hwa Chong Junior College]] (1984–1986), at the latter on a Humanities Award from the [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Ministry of Education]]. She took a [[Bachelor of Arts]] (B.A. (Hons.)) in [[Jurisprudence]] at [[Keble College, Oxford]]<ref name="NUS CV">{{citation|title=Curriculum vitae: Professor (Dr.) THIO Li-ann |url=http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/staffcv/ThioLi_annCV05Feb07.pdf |publisher=[[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|Faculty of Law]], [[National University of Singapore]] |date=5 February 2007 |accessdate=18 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070720210334/http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/staffcv/ThioLi_annCV05Feb07.pdf |archivedate=20 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}.</ref> between 1987 and 1990.<ref name="Parliament"/> At Oxford she was awarded the Law Moderations Book Prize (Constitutional Law, Criminal Law and Roman Law) in 1988. She was called to the Bar as a [[Barristers in England and Wales|barrister]] at [[Gray's Inn]] in 1991.<ref name="NUS CV"/>
==Career as law academic== Thio joined the Faculty of Law of the NUS as a Senior Tutor in 1991, and was appointed Lecturer in 1992. That same year she embarked on postgraduate law studies at [[Harvard Law School]] on a National University of Singapore Overseas Graduate Scholarship, and obtained a [[Master of Laws]] (LL.M.) in 1993.<ref>Her LL.M. thesis was entitled ''Constitutional Interpretation: Lost Lessons from the Fundamental Principles of the U.S. Constitution'' (1993).</ref> She returned to NUS, where in 1997 she was appointed an Assistant Professor. Between 1997 and 2000 she carried out [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] research at the [[University of Cambridge]] on another NUS Overseas Graduate Scholarship, and was duly conferred this degree in 2000. Her Ph.D. dissertation, entitled ''Managing Babel: The International Legal Protection of Minorities in the Twentieth Century'', was subsequently published by [[Martinus Nijhoff]] Publishers in 2005. In June 2000 she was appointed an Associate Professor, and achieved the rank of full Professor in July 2006.<ref name="Parliament"/><ref name="NUS CV"/> Her research interests are the following:
*Constitutionalism and human rights in Asia. *Domestic and comparative perspectives of constitutional law and administrative law. *International human rights law and the rights of peoples. *Law and religion. *Public international law, its history and theory.<ref name="NUS">{{citation|title=Academic profiles: THIO Li-ann |url=http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/profileview.asp?UserID=lawtla |publisher=Faculty of Law, National University of Singapore |date=25 June 2004 |accessdate=16 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015140755/http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/profileview.asp?UserID=lawtla |archivedate=15 October 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}.</ref>
Thio was Young Asian Scholar at the [[Melbourne University Law School]] in 1997,<ref>Thio's ''curriculum vitae'' states that this took place in 1998: {{citation|title=Curriculum vitae: Professor (Dr.) THIO Li-ann |url=http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/staffcv/ThioLi_annCV05Feb07.pdf |format=PDF |publisher=Faculty of Law, National University of Singapore |date=5 February 2007 |accessdate=18 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070720210334/http://law.nus.edu.sg/faculty/staff/staffcv/ThioLi_annCV05Feb07.pdf |archivedate=20 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}.</ref> was ranked as an NUS Excellent Teacher in 2001–2002 and 2002–2003, and was given a Young Researcher Award by NUS in 2004. In March 2006, she was a Visiting Lecturer at the Faculty of Law of the [[University of Hong Kong]], where she was one of the academics teaching a course on "National Protection of Human Rights". In September of that year she returned to the [[University of Melbourne]] as a Senior Fellow of its Graduate Law Programme to teach a course entitled "Constitutionalism in Asian Societies".<ref name="NUS CV"/>
Thio served<ref name="NUS CV"/><ref name="NUS"/> as Chief Editor of the ''Singapore Journal of International & Comparative Law''<ref>{{citation|journal=Singapore Journal of International & Comparative Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Faculty of Law, National University of Singapore|year=1997–2003|issn=0219-0508|title=Singapore yearbook of international law [Serials]|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/singapore-yearbook-of-international-law-serials/oclc/957008186|accessdate=6 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171031010511/https://www.worldcat.org/title/singapore-yearbook-of-international-law-serials/oclc/957008186|archive-date=31 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}. After 2003 the journal was renamed the ''Singapore Year Book of International Law'' (SYBIL).</ref> between 2000 and 2003, and since 2005 has been General Editor of the ''Asian Yearbook of International Law''.<ref>{{citation |title=Asian Yearbook of International Law|location=Dordrecht, The Netherlands|publisher=Martinus Nijhoff|year=1993 |issn=0928-432X |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/asian-yearbook-of-international-law/oclc/485336884 |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref> She is also on the editorial or advisory boards of the ''Singapore Yearbook of International Law'',<ref>{{citation |title=Singapore Year Book of International Law|location=Singapore|publisher=Faculty of Law, National University of Singapore|year=2004|issn=1793-0448 |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/singapore-year-book-of-international-law/oclc/719766706 |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref> the ''New Zealand Yearbook of International Law'' (since 2003),<ref>{{citation|title=New Zealand Yearbook of International Law|location=Christchurch, N.Z.|publisher=International Law Group, School of Law, [[University of Canterbury]]|year=2004|issn=1176-6417 |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/new-zealand-yearbook-of-international-law/oclc/56810014 |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref> the ''University of Bologna Law Review'' (since 2016),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bolognalawreview.unibo.it/about/displayMembership/123|title=Advisory Board|author=|publisher=Bolognalawreview.unibo.it|accessdate=29 August 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160911043624/https://bolognalawreview.unibo.it/about/displayMembership/123|archive-date=11 September 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and ''Human Rights & International Legal Discourse'' (since 2006),<ref>{{citation |title=Human Rights & International Legal Discourse|location=Mortsel, Belgium|publisher=Intersentia|year=2007–2010|issn=1783-7014 |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/human-rights-international-legal-discourse-hr-ild/oclc/830946407 |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref> and is Corresponding Editor (Singapore) for Blaustein & Flanz's ''Constitutions of the Countries of the World'' (since 2001)<ref>{{citation|author=A.P. Blaustein|author2=G.H. Flanz, eds.|title=Constitutions of the Countries of the World: A Series of Updated Texts, Constitutional Chronologies and Annotated Bibliographies|edition=Permanent|location=Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.|publisher=[[Oceana Publications]]|year=1971|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/constitutions-of-the-countries-of-the-world-a-series-of-updated-texts-constitutional-chronologies-and-annotated-bibliographies/oclc/283323438&referer=brief_results |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref> and the ''International Journal of Constitutional Law'' (since 2001).<ref>{{citation|journal=International Journal of Constitutional Law|location=Oxford|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=2003|issn=1474-2640|title=I. CON : International journal of constitutional law.|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/i-con-international-journal-of-constitutional-law/oclc/930424052|accessdate=6 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010051504/https://www.worldcat.org/title/i-con-international-journal-of-constitutional-law/oclc/930424052|archive-date=10 October 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> Since 2001 she has also been a contributor on constitutional and [[administrative law in Singapore|administrative law]] to the ''Singapore Academy of Law Annual Review of Singapore Cases''.<ref>{{citation|title=Singapore Academy of Law Annual Review of Singapore Cases|location=Singapore|publisher=Singapore Academy of Law|year=2001 |issn=0219-6638 |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/singapore-academy-of-law-annual-review-of-singapore-cases/oclc/938292599 |accessdate=6 July 2017}}.</ref>
Thio appeared as an expert witness before the [[Federal Court of Australia]] in the [[extradition]] of Michael McCrea to Singapore to stand trial for murder (2003), and as a consultant to a delegation of the [[House of Representatives of Japan]] (30 September 2002) and to the [[University of Warwick]] on academic freedom issues (2005).<ref name="NUS CV"/>
==Term as Nominated Member of Parliament== {{Original research|date=November 2007}} {{Weasel|date=March 2009}} From 18 January 2007, Thio was appointed a [[Nominated Member of Parliament]] of the 11th Session of the [[Parliament of Singapore]] for a two-and-a-half-year term.<ref name="NUS CV"/>
In October 2007, the [[Parliament of Singapore]] reviewed the [[Penal Code (Singapore)|Penal Code]].<ref>{{Singapore legislation|title=Penal Code|cap=224|ed=1985}}.</ref> In the course of doing so, it decided not to repeal [[Sections 377 and 377A of the Penal Code (Singapore)|section 377A of the Code]] and thus continued to criminalise sexual activity between males. In the course of the debate in Parliament, Thio gave a speech to support the continued criminalisation of sexual activity between males, and likened gay sex to "shoving a straw up your nose to drink."<ref name="nyt-nyu"/> She claimed to have support from a majority of Singaporeans, and stated she spoke "at the risk of being burned at the stake by militant activists."<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Li-ann |title=Speech, Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Penal Code Revisions, 22–23 October 2007 (Professor Dr. Thio Li-ann, Nominated Member) |url=http://keep377a.com/Media/ThioLi-AnnSpeech.pdf |publisher=Keep377A.com |date=23 October 2007 |accessdate=19 November 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228003248/http://keep377a.com/Media/ThioLi-AnnSpeech.pdf |archivedate=28 February 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}.</ref> At the same time, Thio mentioned the existence of an active gay agenda that seeks to lobby the government and radically change sexual norms.<ref name="nyt-nyu"/>
The Internet subsequently saw a flood of websites heavily rebutting Thio's speech, most of which focused on her lurid straw-up-the-nose analogy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/education/23nyu.html|title=Opposition Causes Thio Li-ann to Skip N.Y.U. Appointment|first=Winnie|last=Hu|publisher=|access-date=25 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825033209/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/education/23nyu.html|archive-date=25 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Local journalist Janadas Devan, in a feature article in ''The Straits Times'' on 27 October, titled "377A debate and the rewriting of pluralism", the pointed out that the speech was heavily laced with phrases and imagery from the [[Dominionist]] movement.<ref name="ST 20071027">{{citation|author=Janadas Devan|title=377A debate and the rewriting of pluralism|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=27 October 2007}}.</ref> Another ''Straits Times'' writer, Chua Mui Hoong, also wrote an article titled "Rules of Engagement for God and Politics" on 16 November 2007. In it, Chua acknowledged Thio's position in her speech that secularism could challenge religion. However, Chua disagreed that religion has been antagonised in Singapore, and encouraged that specific explanation be given as to how the repeal of a law would in reality harm the Singaporean society.<ref>{{citation|author=Chua Mui Hong|title=Rules of engagement for God and politics|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=16 November 2007}}.</ref>
Thio's speech also drew the criticism of [[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]], then a judge of the [[High Court of Australia]], who referenced it in a speech he delivered in [[Brisbane]] on 16 November 2007. The content of his speech was subsequently published in ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' on 19 November 2007.<ref>{{citation|author=[[Michael Kirby (judge)|Michael Kirby]]|title=Selective tolerance is not tolerance at all|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/selective-tolerance-is-not-tolerance-at-all/2007/11/18/1195321603784.html|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=19 November 2007|access-date=26 November 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071120235251/http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/selective-tolerance-is-not-tolerance-at-all/2007/11/18/1195321603784.html|archive-date=20 November 2007|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref>
During the debate, Thio revealed that playwright [[Alfian Sa'at]] had sent her a short email saying, among other things, that "I hope I outlive you long enough to see the repeal of 377A and on that day I will piss on your grave."<ref>{{cite web|title=Alfian Sa’at Vs Thio Li-Ann|url=http://pseudonymity.wordpress.com/2007/10/27/alfian-saat-vs-thio-li-ann/|website=Pseudonymity|accessdate=21 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141222053745/http://pseudonymity.wordpress.com/2007/10/27/alfian-saat-vs-thio-li-ann/|archive-date=22 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Sa'at later took responsibility for the email, saying it was sent in a moment of folly in response to the rumour that Thio had called the police to complain about a "Pink Picnic" some members of the gay community were organising in the [[Singapore Botanic Gardens|Botanic Gardens]]. Thio later denied the allegation, and Sa'at apologised. Subsequently, in November 2007, Thio was alerted by the media to an anonymous threatening letter addressed to her stating: "We know where you work, we'll send people there to hunt you down". Thio made a police report the same day.<ref>{{citation|author=Li Xueying|title=NMP Thio files 2nd police report after getting threat|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=8 November 2007}}.</ref>
===Question regarding support from the majority=== Thio's strong position towards retaining the code drew much protest from some Singaporeans. Two issues were constantly raised. The first issue was the question of the real existence of a majority against repeal of the code. The second issue was the question of whether a stance against homosexual behavior would equate to wanting a code to criminalize the act of sodomy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trevvy.com/sgboyx/index.php?showforum=5|title=Trevvy - Forums - Crying OUT Loud Singapore!|first=Trevvy Trevvy.com SGBOY Sgboy.com Gay Singapore Malaysia Hong Kong Thailand Australia News Lifestyle Personals Events Forums|last=Resources|website=www.trevvy.com|access-date=25 November 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121064041/http://www.trevvy.com/sgboyx/index.php?showforum=5|archive-date=21 November 2007|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Concerns were also raised by a law professor on whether it was realistically possible to enforce such a code, whether it would lead to dangers of entrapment, and whether the informal position of the government not to enforce the code would reverse overnight.<ref>{{citation|author=K.C. Vijayan|title=NUS don warns of 377A fallout|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=30 October 2007}}.</ref>
At the same time, an alleged email also surfaced during the course of discussion, in which Senior Pastor Derek Hong of [[Church of Our Saviour, Singapore]], supposedly encouraged acquaintances to lobby the government to decide against repealing the code.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psa91.com/pdf/derek_hong.htm|title=Elim Sanctuary - Gays & Christianity - Email from Derek Hong|website=www.psa91.com|access-date=25 November 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028113654/http://www.psa91.com/pdf/derek_hong.htm|archive-date=28 October 2007|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The email contains a suggested format of writing, which could be found repeated heavily in actual letters to ''The Straits Times'' and [http://www.reach.gov.sg reach.gov.sg], the Singaporean government online feedback website. The content of the alleged email is strongly similar to an earlier one sent in 2003 by [[Cornerstone Community Church]]. Neither Hong nor his church has issued any statement on this matter.
==NYU Law School controversy== Thio was to be a visiting human rights professor at [[New York University School of Law]] in the fall of 2009 until she withdrew her acceptance in July 2009.<ref>{{citation|author=[[Richard Revesz|Richard L. Revesz]]|title=Statement from Dean Richard L. Revesz of the New York University School of Law|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/nyregion/23nyu-text.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=22 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172715/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/nyregion/23nyu-text.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1|archive-date=10 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref><ref name="afp-nyu">{{citation|title=Anti-gay Singapore prof cancels NYU stint after uproar|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/antigay-singapore-prof-cancels-nyu-stint-after-uproar-20090724-dvxb.html|newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=24 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725224656/http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/antigay-singapore-prof-cancels-nyu-stint-after-uproar-20090724-dvxb.html|archive-date=25 July 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> Many noted the irony in her appointment, and prompted calls for condemnation of her "anti-gay hate speech" before Parliament.<ref name="nyt-nyu">{{citation|author=Winnie Hu|title=Citing opposition, professor calls off N.Y.U. appointment|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/education/23nyu.html?scp=1&sq=Li-ann%20Thio&st=cse|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=22 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910125635/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/23/education/23nyu.html?scp=1&sq=Li-ann%20Thio&st=cse|archive-date=10 September 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> The University's gay and lesbian law student group, NYU OUTLaw, released a statement calling for the condemnation.<ref>{{citation|author=David Lat|title=NYU professor of human rights: Not a fan of gay rights?|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/thio_li_ann_hates_perversity.php|publisher=[[Above the Law (blog)|Above the Law]]|date=6 June 2009|accessdate=11 June 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090708012937/http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/thio_li_ann_hates_perversity.php|archivedate=8 July 2009|df=dmy-all}}; {{citation|title=Rights for some people|url=http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/07/08/nyu|publisher=[[Inside Higher Ed]]|date=8 June 2009|accessdate=11 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090711083152/http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/07/08/nyu|archive-date=11 July 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}; {{citation|author=Julie Bolcer|title=Human rights prof. opposes gay rights|url=http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid97380.asp|date=10 July 2009|accessdate=11 June 2009|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090713025531/http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid97380.asp|archivedate=13 July 2009|df=dmy-all}}.</ref><ref name="tnp-nyu">{{citation|author=Tay Shi'an|title=She's not against gay people, just against gay agenda|url=http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090720-155956.html|newspaper=[[The New Paper]]|date=22 July 2009|accessdate=24 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724081845/http://www.asiaone.com/News/Education/Story/A1Story20090720-155956.html|archive-date=24 July 2009|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}.</ref><ref name="st-nyu">{{citation|author=Cai Haoxiang|title=Thio Li-ann cancels teaching stint at NYU|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]|date=24 July 2009|page=A15}}.</ref>
NYU Law School's Dean Richard Revesz issued a memorandum stating "the Law School categorically rejects the point of view expressed in Professor Thio's speech, as evidenced by our early and longstanding commitment to end discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation."<ref name=atlstt>{{citation|author=David Lat|title=Dr. Li-ann Thio: The good professor speaks – and so does NYU Law School|url=http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/li_ann_thio_will_kick_your_pansy_ass.php|publisher=Above the Law|date=10 July 2009|accessdate=13 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712073120/http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/li_ann_thio_will_kick_your_pansy_ass.php|archivedate=12 July 2009|df=dmy-all}}.</ref> Students at NYU Law School have issued statements as well.
Thio then sent an 18-point defense memo to the entire NYU Law faculty.<ref name="tnp-nyu"/> On 22 July 2009, she informed the school of her withdrawal from the appointment, citing hostility by its community towards her views and low enrollment.<ref name="afp-nyu"/><ref name="st-nyu"/> It was reported that only 9 students applied for her course on Human Rights and 5 for her another course on Constitutionalism.<ref>{{cite web | access-date=25 July 2009 | archive-date=18 July 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090718110516/http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/li_ann_thio_has_no_students.php | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all | url=http://abovethelaw.com/2009/07/li_ann_thio_has_no_students.php | title=Dr. Li-ann Thio: Much Ado About Nothing? | publisher=Above the Law | author=Lat, David}}</ref>
==Personal life==
===Daughter of Thio Su Mien=== Thio's father is Thio Gim Hock and her brother is senior counsel Thio Shen Yi. Her maternal grandfather is Reverend Huang Yang Ying, first principal of [[Anglican High School, Singapore|Anglican High School]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/printheritage/image.aspx?id=00e7500e-8be4-477d-9842-f7904c82d358 | title=Dr. Thio Su Mien with her young children, 1971 | website=BooksSG | access-date=29 July 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803122110/http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/printheritage/image.aspx?id=00e7500e-8be4-477d-9842-f7904c82d358 | archive-date=3 August 2017 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Her mother is Dr. (Mrs.) [[Thio Su Mien]], who was formerly the Dean of the Faculty of Law of the National University of Singapore, and is now in private practice. Dr. Thio Su Mien came to the attention of the Singaporean public in 2003 when she sent a letter to ''The Straits Times'' stating her strong disagreement with homosexuality.<ref>{{citation|author=Thio Su Mien|title=No to homosexuality|newspaper=[[Streats]]|date=22 July 2003}}.</ref> The letter, signed by eight persons, was in response to a speech by the then [[Prime Minister of Singapore|Prime Minister]] [[Goh Chok Tong]] in which he mentioned that the [[Civil service|Civil Service]] would not discriminate against employing homosexual individuals. On 9 February 2006, Dr Thio Su Mien also wrote another letter to ''The Straits Times'' which, amongst other things, stated her belief that the [[American Psychiatric Association]] had ceased to regard homosexuality as a [[mental disorder]] due to "[[American Psychiatric Association#History|pressure tactics from homosexual activists]] — including riots and disruptions of APA meetings".<ref>{{citation|author=M. Nirmala|title=Gay backlash|newspaper=[[The Straits Times]]|date=23 July 2003}}.</ref>
====[[Association of Women for Action and Research|AWARE]] Takeover by Thio Su Mien====
In 2009, a group of conservative Christian women from the [[Church of Our Saviour, Singapore|Church of Our Savior]], under the leadership of Josie Lau and orchestrated by Dr Thio Su Mien, took over the executive council of the group alleging [[Association of Women for Action and Research|AWARE]], a non-governmental organization in Singapore concerned with promoting gender equality. 6 of the 11 newly elected executive committee were church members who had only joined the group 3 months prior to the election, and 80 of the 120 attendees of the meeting were similarly new members from the church.<ref>{{citation|author=Kalinga Seneviratne|title=SINGAPORE: Evangelical Christians Take on Civil Society|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2009/04/singapore-evangelical-christians-take-on-civil-society/|date=30 April 2009|access-date=19 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120023303/http://www.ipsnews.net/2009/04/singapore-evangelical-christians-take-on-civil-society/|archive-date=20 January 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The old guard called for a no-confidence vote and the new council was voted out of office on 2 May 2009.<ref>"Taken unawares; Singapore's NGO furore," in: ''The Economist'', 9 May 2009</ref> Of the 2,175 people who voted at the meeting, 1,414 voted for the no-confidence.<ref>Yong, Debbie. 2009. "Getting to know Aware's new exco; Members talk about EGM, its sex education programme and plans for future over dinner," in: ''The Straits Times'', 10 May.</ref> Deputy Prime minister [[Wong Kan Seng]] commented that "a group of conservative Christians, all attending the same church, which held strong views on homosexuality, had moved in and taken over AWARE because they disapproved of what AWARE had been doing", and called for tolerance, cautioning that religion and politics must be kept separate.<ref>[http://www.mha.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=MTQ0MA%3D%3D-H1aIkdI4Ksw%3D Comments by DPM and Minister for Home Affairs Wong Kan Seng in response to media queries related to AWARE ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517040507/http://www.mha.gov.sg/news_details.aspx?nid=MTQ0MA%3D%3D-H1aIkdI4Ksw%3D |date=17 May 2009 }}</ref>
On May 26, 2009, during Thio Li Ann's first speech in parliament since the event, Thio Li-Ann accused the local press of biased reporting on the events surrounding the attempted takeover. Han Fook Kwang, then editor of the Straits Times, responded in an editorial and expressed his sadness at the vindictiveness of "critics and the length to which they are prepared to go to attack our professionalism" and integrity, detailing the sequence of events and how their journalists had investigated and reported on the proceedings.<ref>{{citation|author=Han Fook Kwang|title=How ST covered the story|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=30 May 2009}}.</ref>
===Religious affiliation=== Thio is a Christian. In an interview with the local daily ''[[The Straits Times]]'' on 2 November 2007, Thio shared her personal story of how she converted from a "very, very arrogant" atheist to a Christian in 1987.<ref name="nyt-nyu"/> Having entered Oxford University to read jurisprudence, she attended a Christian Union talk then and claimed to be "stopped" by a voice.
"I basically had a sense that God was talking to me. I had stood up to walk out and I heard someone say, 'Stop'. And no one was around me. Everybody was busy doing their own thing. I was one of only one or two Chinese girls in this whole room of [[ang moh]]s. And then I just had the sense that I had encountered God, that he knew my name and I was shocked." Thio was quoted as saying in the interview.<ref>{{citation|author=Li Xueying|title=A fiery NMP gets her baptism of fire|newspaper=The Straits Times|date=2 November 2007}}.</ref>
She added, "'I don't know what [[right wing]] is. This is funny because I was always considered a political leftie and now I'm a rightie."

{{Infobox treaty |name = Treaty of Kiel |type = [[Peace treaty]] |long_name = {{native name|no|Kieltraktaten}}
{{native name|sv|Freden i Kiel}} |image = Öfwersättning af de Artiklar emellan Konungarne af Swerige og Dannemark.djvu |image_width = 200px |caption = Translated reprint of the part concerned with Norway |date_signed = 14 January 1814 |location_signed = [[Kiel]], [[Duchy of Holstein]] |context = [[War of the Sixth Coalition]] during the [[Napoleonic Wars]] |parties = {{Plainlist}} * {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] * {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Denmark–Norway]] * {{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Kingdom of Sweden|Sweden]] {{Endplainlist}} |language = [[French language|French]] }} The '''Treaty of Kiel''' ({{lang-no|Kieltraktaten}}) or '''Peace of Kiel''' ([[Swedish language|Swedish]] and {{lang-no|Kielfreden}} or ''{{lang|sv|freden i Kiel}}'') was concluded between the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] and the [[Kingdom of Sweden]] on one side and the [[Denmark–Norway|Kingdoms of Denmark and Norway]] on the other side on 14 January 1814 in [[Kiel]].Schäfer (2002), p. 137 It ended the hostilities between the parties in the ongoing [[Napoleonic Wars]], where the United Kingdom and Sweden were part of the anti-French camp (the [[War of the Sixth Coalition|Sixth Coalition]]) while Denmark–Norway was allied to [[Napoleon Bonaparte]]. [[Frederick VI of Denmark]] joined the anti-French alliance, ceded [[Heligoland]] to [[George III of the United Kingdom]], and further ceded the [[Kingdom of Norway]] to [[Charles XIII of Sweden]] in return for [[Swedish Pomerania]]. Specifically excluded from the exchange were the Norwegian dependencies of [[Greenland]], [[Iceland]] and the [[Faroe Islands]], which remained in the union with Denmark.Dörr (2004), p. 103 (Norway would unsuccessfully contest the Danish claim to all of Greenland in the [[Eastern Greenland Case]] of 1931–33.Cavell (2008), pp. 433ff) However, not all provisions of the treaty would come into force. Norway declared its independence, adopted a [[Constitution of Norway|constitution]] and elected Crown [[Christian VIII of Denmark|Prince Christian Frederik]] as its own king. Sweden therefore refused to hand over [[Swedish Pomerania]], which instead passed to [[Prussia]] after the [[Congress of Vienna]] in 1815. After a short [[Swedish-Norwegian War (1814)|war with Sweden]], Norway accepted entering into a [[Union between Sweden and Norway|personal union with Sweden]] at the [[Convention of Moss]]. King Christian Frederik abdicated after convening an extraordinary [[Parliament|Storting]], which revised the Constitution to allow for the Union. It was formally established when the Storting elected Charles XIII as king of Norway on 4 November 1814. ==Background== {{see also|War of the Sixth Coalition}} In the beginning of the [[Napoleonic Wars]], [[Denmark-Norway]] and the [[Kingdom of Sweden]] tried to maintain neutralityOlesen (2008), p. 285 but soon became involved in the fighting, joining opposite camps. Swedish king [[Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden|Gustav IV Adolf]] entered an alliance with the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] and the [[Russian Empire]] against [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] in 1804, and declared war on [[Napoleonic France]] in 1805. The United Kingdom, which had declared war on France in 1803, paid subsidies to Sweden. Before Gustav IV Adolf marched his forces out of [[Swedish Pomerania]], [[Brandenburg-Pomeranian conflict|a province long coveted by Prussia]], he negotiated an agreement that Prussia would not attack it. Denmark remained neutral. [[File:CarlXIVJohnSweden.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Jean Baptiste Bernadotte]]]] In 1807, Napoleonic forces [[Siege of Stralsund (1807)|seized Swedish Pomerania]] and forced Prussia and Russia to sign the [[Treaty of Tilsit]].Olesen (2008), p. 287 Russia was therein obliged to attack Napoleon's enemies, and since Gustav IV Adolf refused to break his alliance with the United Kingdom, the tsar invaded [[Finland]] and [[Treaty of Fredrikshamn|severed it from Sweden]] in the [[Finnish War]], 1808/1809. [[Anglo-Swedish War (1810–1812)|Sweden could no longer uphold her anti-French foreign policy]], and French Marshal [[Jean Baptiste Bernadotte]] was elected heir to the Swedish throne in 1810. Denmark-Norway entered an alliance with France after the [[Battle of Copenhagen (1807)|second British bombardment of Copenhagen]] in 1807.Olesen (2008), p. 289 In 1812, Napoleon's forces were decimated in their failed attempt to subdue Russia, and started their westward retreat.Büsch (1992), p. 39 Sweden allied with Russia on 30 August 1812, with the United Kingdom on 3 March 1813,{{cite book| title= Diplomatisches Handbuch: Sammlung der wichtigsten europaeischen Friedensschluesse, Congressacten und sonstigen Staatsurkunden, vom westphaelischen Frieden bis auf die neueste Zeit| volume= 2| first1= Friedrich Wilhelm |last1= Ghillany| first2= C. H. | last2= Beck| year= 1855| trans-title= Diplomatic Handbook: Collection of the Most Important European Peace Conventions, Congress Acts and Other State Certificates, from the Westphalia Peace to the Modern Period | language= German}} and with Prussia on 22 April 1813.Büsch (1992), p. 60 Previously, on 23 March 1813, she had declared war on Napoleon. Bernadotte's condition for entering the anti-Napoleonic alliance was the gain of Norway, which the United Kingdom and Russia accepted in May 1813. Prussia however did not acknowledge this claim at first. Thus, Bernadotte hesitated to enter the war with full force, and only engaged in a campaign against [[Hamburg]] which on 30 June was re-conquered by allied French and Danish forces.Büsch (1992), p. 61 When Prussia finally accepted the Swedish claim to Norway on 22 July, Sweden joined the [[Treaties of Reichenbach (1813)|alliance of Reichenbach]] concluded between Russia, the United Kingdom and Prussia on 14/15 June. With three armies (North, Main and [[Silesia]]n, the Northern army under Bernadotte's command), the allies subsequently cleared [[Northern Germany]] of French forces. Denmark, who had maintained the alliance with Napoleon because of the Swedish claim to Norway, was isolated and, as a consequence of the war, bankrupt.Cranshaw (2007), p. 22 ==Dano-British treaty== The treaty between the [[Kingdom of Denmark]] and the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]] was negotiated by Danish diplomat [[Edmund Bourke (1761-1821)|Edmund Bourke]] and the British envoy at the Swedish court, [[Edward Thornton (1766–1852)|Edward Thornton]]. It consisted of 14 articles, to which two articles were added in [[Brussels]] on 7 April. {{multiple image|image1=Fiedrichvidenmark.jpg|image2=George III of the United Kingdom.jpg|footer=[[Frederick VI of Denmark]] (left) and [[George III of the United Kingdom]]|width1=150|width2=167}} In article III, the United Kingdom was obliged to return all occupied Danish possessions to the Danish king. Excepted was the island of [[Heligoland]], where the British king was granted "full and unlimited sovereignty". In article VI, the Danish king joined the anti-[[Napoleonic France|Napoleonic]] alliance, and obliged himself to maintain an army of 10,000 men that was to be joined to the Allied forces in Northern Germany and likewise be commanded by the Swedish crown prince.Jenssen-Tusch (1852), p. 169 This Danish contingent was to be treated the same way the Swedish contingent was treated, and the Danish king was to receive an annual 400,000 pounds of British subsidies for maintenance and pay of the army, to be paid in monthly installments as soon as the army entered Allied service. Article VIII was concerned with the abolishment of [[slave trade]]. In article X, the British king promised the Danish king to negotiate further compensation for Denmark's territorial cessions to Sweden in a pending final peace. In article XIII, older Dano-British treaties were confirmed. The articles added in Brussels were concerned with the property of Danish subjects in the colonies or in ceded territories, which was to remain untouched by the British for the next three years, and equal treatment of Danish, British and Hanoveranian subjects, who were not to be prosecuted because of their participation in the war on different sides, nor because of their political or religious beliefs. ==Dano-Swedish treaty== [[File:Gustaf af Wetterstedt (from Hildebrand, Sveriges historia).jpg|thumb|150px|[[Gustaf af Wetterstedt|Wetterstedt]]]] The treaty between the [[Kingdom of Denmark]] and the [[Kingdom of Sweden]] was negotiated by Danish diplomat [[Edmund Bourke (1761-1821)|Edmund Bourke]] (Burke) and Swedish envoy Baron [[Gustaf af Wetterstedt]] with British mediation.Jenssen-Tusch (1852), p. 165 It consisted of 28 articles and one separate article. In article III, the Danish king promised to join the alliance against [[Napoleonic France]],Jenssen-Tusch (1852), pp. 165–166 and with reference to the Dano-British treaty confirms his obligation to put part of his army under Swedish command.Jenssen-Tusch (1852), p. 166 In article IV, the Danish king in his and his successors' name "irrevocably and forever" renounced claims to the [[Kingdom of Norway]] in favor of the Swedish king. The Norwegian kingdom was defined as consisting of the bishoprics of [[Christiansand]], [[Bergen]], [[Akershus]] and [[Trondheim]], as well as the coastal islands and the northern regions of [[Nordland]] and [[Finnmark]] to the Russian border. Excepted were [[Greenland]], [[Iceland]] and the [[Faroe Islands]]. The Norwegian subjects were freed of their obligations to the Danish king. In article VI, the Swedish crown took over the debts and financial obligations of Norway, which was to be determined by a joint Dano-Swedish commission. Article VII ruled that [[Swedish Pomerania]] was to be handed over to Denmark. In article XV, it was ruled that the Swedish forces were to take over the Norwegian fortresses as soon as the treaty was ratified, and that they were to abandon Swedish Pomerania as soon as the Norwegian fortresses [[Fredriksten]], [[Fredrikstad Fortress|Fredrikstad]], [[Kongsvinger]] and [[Akershus Fortress|Akershus]] were handed over.Jenssen-Tusch (1852), p. 167 In article XIII, the Swedish king promised the Danish king to negotiate full compensation for the cession of Norway in a pending final peace, and the cession of Swedish Pomerania is described as a "proof" of this intention. [[File:Charles XIII of Sweden.jpg|thumb|175px|left|[[Charles XIII of Sweden]]]] In article XII, the king of Sweden promised to maintain the Norwegian [[University of Oslo|University]] of Christiania, and the Pomeranian [[University of Greifswald]], which was to pass to Denmark according to article VII, and confirmed donations made before the exchange. Also, it was agreed in article XX that subjects of the Danish king could choose within the next six years whether they would finally settle in Norway or Denmark, whereby property in the realm which would not become the permanent residence was to be sold only to inhabitants of this realm. This provision was also enacted with respect to Swedish Pomerania. In article XVI, it was agreed that the governors general and all foreign-born officials of the exchanged territories, as long as they did not decide to remain, were removed from their offices. Article XXI obliged the Danish administration to hand over all civilian and military administrative documents and archives concerning Norway.Jenssen-Tusch (1852), p. 168 Article XVII provided for a mutual exchange of all prisoners of war. According to article XV, allied troops were to leave the Danish [[Holstein-Glückstadt|Duchy of Schleswig]] (Slesvig), but were allowed to remain in the [[German Confederation|German confederal]] [[Duchy of Holstein]] (Holsten), ruled in [[personal union]] with Denmark and Schleswig, to participate in the encirclement of [[Hamburg]]. In article XXVII, former Dano-Swedish peaces were confirmed as long as their provisions were not in conflict with the treaty of Kiel, namely the [[Treaty of Copenhagen (1660)]], the [[Treaty of Stockholm (Great Northern War)|Treaty of Stockholm (June 1720)]], the [[Treaty of Frederiksborg]] (July 1720) and the [[Treaty of Jönköping]] (1809). A separate article was concerned with the cession of hostilities. ==Impact== ===The personal union of Sweden and Norway=== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2017}} {{main|Union between Sweden and Norway}} [[File:Eidsvoll riksraad 1814.jpeg|300px|thumb|[[Constitution of Norway|Norwegian Constituent Assembly]] at [[Eidsvoll]], 1814.]] On hearing news of the treaty, which became known through proclamation at the end of January, and published in Norwegian newspapers soon after, Norwegians were in disarray, and many called for arms, having beaten the Swedes only five years prior, in the 1809 campaign. A virtual independence movement had been established as early as 1810, and this movement gained momentum in the brooding situation. The Crown Prince of [[Denmark-Norway|Denmark and Norway]], [[Christian Frederik|Christian Frederick]], the resident viceroy in Norway, used this opportunity to intervene. He took the helm in the [[Norway in 1814|Norwegian independence movement]], most likely with the surreptitious goal of re-unification with Denmark. This was not in the interest of all Norwegians. In fact, the founders of the 1810 movement lobbied for an independent Norway. The initiative of Christian Frederick was successful, partly due to clandestine support from the Danish [[The Crown|Crown]], but also because it was supported by prominent and influential Norwegians. They convinced the Prince that it would be unwise to claim the throne as his inheritance. Instead they advised him to assume the regency and call an election of representatives to a constituent assembly. On 10 April the national assembly met at [[Eidsvoll]] to decide on a [[Constitution of Norway|Constitution]]. Norway eventually declared independence on 17 May 1814, electing Christian Frederick as King. (The seventeenth of May is "Syttende mai" or [[Norwegian Constitution Day]] that is celebrated by Norwegians at home and abroad.) This triggered [[Swedish-Norwegian War (1814)|a short war with Sweden]] in which Sweden's financial advantage proved too much to overcome. Nevertheless, when cease-fire talks began, Bernadotte made an important concession—he accepted the newly adopted Norwegian constitution, thus giving up any claim that Norway was to be treated as merely a Swedish province. In accordance with the [[Convention of Moss]], Norway agreed to enter [[union between Sweden and Norway|a personal union with Sweden]]. After having made the necessary amendments to the constitution, the Norwegian [[Storting]] on 4 November elected [[Charles XIII of Sweden]] as King of Norway, creating the [[union between Sweden and Norway]]. ===Swedish Pomerania=== {{further|Congress of Vienna}} [[File:Hardenberg.jpg|thumb|150px|left|[[Karl August von Hardenberg|Hardenberg]]]] Due to the refusal of Norway to subordinate itself to the Swedish king, [[Charles XIII of Sweden]] did not hand over [[Swedish Pomerania]] to [[Frederick VI of Denmark]].Büsch (1992), p. 104 The problem was solved at the [[Congress of Vienna]], when the Great Powers followed a plan worked out by [[Karl August von Hardenberg]], [[Minister President of Prussia|prime minister of]] the [[Kingdom of Prussia]], who proposed a ring exchange of territories and payments between the [[Kingdom of Denmark]], the [[Kingdom of Hanover]] (ruled in personal union with [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Great Britain and Ireland]]), the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] and the [[Kingdom of Sweden]]. According to Hardenberg's plan, Prussia ceded [[East Frisia]] with [[Emden]] to Hanover, and in exchange received from Hanover the [[Duchy of Lauenburg]]. This duchy was then handed over from Prussia to Denmark, along with an additional payment of 3.5 million [[Thaler|taler]]s. Prussia also took over a Danish debt to Sweden of 600,000 talers, and agreed on an additional payment of 2 million talers to Sweden. Denmark and Sweden in turn relinquished their claims to Swedish Pomerania in favour of Prussia. Charles XIII of Sweden then released his Pomeranian subjects from their obligations towards Sweden on 1 October 1815, and on 23 October the province was handed over to von Ingersleben, president of [[Province of Pomerania (1653–1815)|Prussian Pomerania]]. ===East Greenland case=== [[File:EricTheRedsLand-no.PNG|thumb|150px|[[Eirik Raudes Land|Eirik Raudes (Erik the Red's) Land]] (blue)]] Between 1931 and 1933, Norway contested the Danish possession of all of Greenland at the [[Permanent Court of International Justice]] in [[The Hague]]. {{As of|2008|12}}, this was the only case where possession of a polar territory was ever decided by an international court. The Norwegian side argued that Denmark did not hold rights to any part of the island where she did not exact actual sovereignty, and accordingly proclaimed a Norwegian [[Eirik Raudes Land]] in eastern Greenland on 10 July 1931, which had been occupied in the previous month.Cavell (2008), p. 434 On 5 April 1933 however, the court ruled that on the basis of the Treaty of Kiel and subsequent treaties, Denmark was the sovereign over the whole of Greenland.Dörr (2004), pp. 103ff ==See also== *[[History of Norway]] *[[Scandinavia]] *[[Norway in 1814]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} '''Bibliography''' {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Büsch|first=Otto|title=Handbuch der preußischen Geschichte|year=1992|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=3-11-008322-1|language=German|volume=3}} *{{cite journal|last=Cavell|first=Janice|title=Historical Evidence and the Eastern Greenland Case|journal=ARCTIC|date=December 2008|volume=61|issue=4|pages=433–441|url=http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic61-4-433.pdf|accessdate=19 June 2010}} *{{cite book|last=Cranshaw|first=Friedrich L.|title=Insolvenz- und finanzrechtliche Perspektiven der Insolvenz von juristischen Personen des öffentlichen Rechts, insbesondere Kommunen|volume=7|series=Schriften zum deutschen, europäischen und internationalen Insolvenzrecht |year=2007|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=3-89949-389-3|language=German}} *{{cite book|last=Dörr|first=Oliver|title=Kompendium völkerrechtlicher Rechtsprechung|year=2004|publisher=Mohr Siebeck|isbn=3-16-148311-1|language=German}} *{{cite book|last=Olesen|first=Jens E.|title=Das Ende des Alten Reiches im Ostseeraum. Wahrnehmungen und Transformationen|year=2008|publisher=Böhlau|isbn=3-412-20108-1|editor=North, Michael |editor2=Riemer, Robert|pages=274–292|language=German|chapter=Schwedisch-Pommern in der schwedischen Politik nach 1806}} *{{cite book|last=Schäfer|first=Anton|title=Zeittafel der Rechtsgeschichte. {{italictitle|force=true}} '''''Tyrer v. the United Kingdom''''' (application No. 5856/72) was a case decided by the [[European Court of Human Rights]] in 1978.
==Facts==
Mr Tyrer, then aged 15, was given [[birching|three strokes of the birch]] in 1972 in the [[Isle of Man]], according to the local juvenile court's sentence for unlawful assault occasioning actual bodily harm. Birching was conducted by policemen in private, in the presence of Tyrer's father and a doctor; Tyrer was made to take down his trousers and underpants and bend over a table.<ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=695464&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECtHR Judgment in case Tyrer v. the United Kingdom, Para. 9-10]</ref>
==Judgment==
By a majority of six votes to one, the Court held Tyrer's birching to constitute degrading treatment contrary to the Article 3 of the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. Significant conclusions of the case included that "the Convention is a living instrument which, as the Commission rightly stressed, must be interpreted in the light of present-day conditions. In the case now before it the Court cannot but be influenced by the developments and commonly accepted standards in the penal policy of the member States of the [[Council of Europe]] in this field".<ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=695464&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECtHR Judgment in case Tyrer v. the United Kingdom, Para. 31]</ref>
Judge [[Gerald Fitzmaurice]] has [[Dissenting opinion|dissented]], finding no violation of Article 3 and concerning that the Court's conclusion "amounts to a finding that all corporal punishment, in all circumstances, inherently involves, as such, an unacceptable level of degradation."<ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=695464&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECtHR Judgment in case Tyrer v. the United Kingdom, separate opinion of Sir Gerard Fitzmaurice, Para. 7]</ref> and that "assuming that corporal punishment does involve some degree of degradation, it has never been seen as doing so for a juvenile to anything approaching the same manner or extent as for an adult" <ref>[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=695464&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECtHR Judgment in case Tyrer v. the United Kingdom, separate opinion of Sir Gerard Fitzmaurice, Para. 11]</ref>
==Aftermath==
The judgment was considered 'landmark' by [[Manfred Nowak]], UN Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.<ref>[http://www2.ohchr.org/english/bodies/hrcouncil/docs/10session/A.HRC.10.44AEV.pdf Report of the Special Rapporteur on torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment A/HRC/10/44 Para. 35]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=open&documentId=803330&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 Commission report] *[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=695464&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 ECtHR Judgment] *[http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=693308&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649 Committee of Ministers resolution]

Jerrold Nadler (D, NY-10)]] | number of co-sponsors = 16 | public law url = | cite public law = | cite statutes at large = | acts affected = [[Cuban Adjustment Act]], [[Cuban Refugee Adjustment Act]], [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952|Immigration and Nationality Act]], [[LIFE Act]], [[Miscellaneous Appropriations Act, 2001]] | acts repealed = | title affected = | sections created = | sections affected = | agenciesaffected = [[Department of Homeland Security]], | authorizationsofappropriations = | appropriations = | leghisturl = | introducedin = House | introducedbill = {{USBill|113|hr|519}} | introducedby = [[Jerrold Nadler|Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D, NY-10)]] | introduceddate = February 5, 2013 | committees = [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary]], | passedbody1 = | passeddate1 = | passedvote1 = | passedbody2 = | passedas2 = | passeddate2 = | passedvote2 = | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = | agreeddate3 = | agreedvote3 = | agreedbody4 = | agreeddate4 = | agreedvote4 = | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = | signeddate = | unsignedpresident = | unsigneddate = | vetoedpresident = | vetoeddate = | overriddenbody1 = | overriddendate1 = | overriddenvote1 = | overriddenbody2 = | overriddendate2 = | overriddenvote2 = | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Uniting American Families Act''' ('''UAFA''', {{USBill|113|H.R.|519}}, {{USBill|113|S.|296}}) is a [[United States|U.S.]] bill to amend the [[Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952]] to eliminate [[discrimination]] in immigration by permitting [[#Definitions of Permanent Partner and Permanent Partnership|permanent partners]] of United States citizens and of lawful [[permanent resident]]s to obtain lawful permanent resident status in the same manner as spouses of citizens and of lawful permanent residents and to penalize immigration fraud in connection with [[#Definitions of Permanent Partner and Permanent Partnership|permanent partnerships]].{{USBill|113|H.R.|519}}{{USBill|113|S.|296}} If the partnership ends within two years, the sponsored partner's immigrant status would be subject to review. Beginning in the 111th Congress, the full text of UAFA, further expanded to provide rights to the children or stepchildren of the foreign-born partner, has been included as Title II of the [[Reuniting Families Act]] ({{USBill|113|H.R.|717}}), an immigration reform bill, last introduced in the United States House of Representatives on February 14, 2013, by [[California]] Congressman [[Michael Honda]] (D-CA).[http://honda.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=90&Itemid=76], Title II - Uniting American Families Act.{{USBill|113|H.R.|717}} UAFA was introduced on February 13, 2013, in the [[United States Senate]] by [[Vermont]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Patrick Leahy]] (D-VT)Senator Patrick Leahy (February 13, 2013).[http://www.leahy.senate.gov/press/leahy-and-collins-introduce-bipartisan-uniting-american-families-act] Press Release. and in the [[United States House of Representatives]] by [[New York (state)|New York]] [[United States Congress|Congressman]] [[Jerrold Nadler]] (D-NY).Representative Jerrold Nadler (February 5, 2013). [http://nadler.house.gov/press-release/momentum-comprehensive-immigration-reform-grows-nadler-and-bipartisan-coalition] Press Release. The Senate version has 29 cosponsors.U.S. Senate. 113th Congress, 1st Session. op. cit., see Cosponsors. The Senate legislation has been referred to the Senate Committee on the Judiciary.http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s113-296 Most of the cosponsors are Democrats and there is little Republican support for the legislation.''National Journal'': [http://www.nationaljournal.com/njonline/no_20100113_1390.php David Gauvey Herbert, "Uniting American Families Act," October 27, 2010], accessed March 5, 2012 The 2013 bill was cosponsored by Republican Congressmen [[Charlie Dent]] and [[Richard L. Hanna]]. There are an estimated 36,000 same-sex binational couples in 2000, according to the Census, who could benefit from this act.http://www.gaylesbiantimes.com/?id=5331&issue=915 == Definitions of Permanent Partner and Permanent Partnership == UAFA includes the following definitions:U.S. House. 113th Congress, 1st Session. op. cit., see Text of Legislation, Sec. 2.
The term "permanent partner" means an individual 18 years of age or older who-- :(A) is in a committed, intimate relationship with another individual 18 years of age or older in which both parties intend a lifelong commitment; :(B) is financially interdependent with that other individual; :(C) is not married to or in a permanent partnership with anyone other than that other individual; :(D) is unable to contract with that other individual a marriage cognizable under this Act; and :(E) is not a first, second, or third degree blood relation of that other individual. The term "permanent partnership" means the relationship that exists between two permanent partners.
